content:
We received a user request for temporarily pausing desktop notifications, e.g. turning them off for 30 minutes at the start of a meeting. I'm wondering what folks think about where we would put this feature.

Looking at other apps, perhaps it belongs on the user card, alongside status/availability options, and in the personal menu once we have one (#22802)?

Screen-Shot-2023-05-26-at-2.40.02-PM.png

We could also think about a version of this for the desktop app (which has a "Do Not Disturb" button, which would let you pause notifications across all your Zulip orgs.

This feels like something that belongs more at an OS configuration level? For example, if I were to run not just Zulip but plenty of other apps, should I expect them to all have this feature, and if they did, should I go through each one at the start of a meeting?

I'm not sure what exists in Linux and Mac for comparison, but does eg. Focus Assist on Windows achieve something comparable?
I agree it ideally would be an OS-level thing. If there are good OS features for this, doing our own documentation for those would likely be a good idea.
Probably doing something ourselves is going to be the most reasonable option though.

For reference from other chat apps:

  • Slack has this option

  • Mattermost has this option

  • Teams expects you to do meetings via Teams, I guess, so they offer auto-muting for meetings.
